_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Van Drunen Farms (VDF) located in Momence, IL.supplies an extensive line of conventional and organic dehydrated, whole-food fruits, vegetables, herbs and other natural, functional food ingredients, and frozen herbs and vegetables, for use in a variety of applications spanning the processed food industry. The products that are produced at VDF use different methods to produce the finished product. One of the methods is through the freeze-drying application that involves the use of anhydrous ammonia. Fruits, vegetables, and other food ingredients are dehydrated through vacuum chambers. Anhydrous ammonia is used to chill and condense the water coming from chambers to execute the drying process. Refrigeration storage and quick freezing are the other methods that require anhydrous ammonia usage. 

There are two VDF plants separate of each other equipped with anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems, each plant having two large separate systems. All four refrigeration systems are two stage systems. Each system is at or under the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard threshold limit of 10,000 lbs. VDF as required by law has developed a PSM Safety Program encompassing all of the required elements of the standard. The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs were developed to meet those requirements and to provide safe measures to prevent or minimize releases. Each element of the VDF prevention program is explained below individually:

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
All employees affected or potentially affected by the ammonia refrigeration systems operating at VDF facilities are part of the PSM Program. Employee participation is part of the development, implementation and review of elements covered under the PSM standard. Employees have access to PHA analyses and all other information developed under the PSM standard. New employees are made aware of ammonia refrigeration systems and the PSM elements as a part of the initial orientation

process. 

A PSM Committee was developed to involve employees. The role of the PSM committee is to develop, implement and manage elements subject to the PSM standard. This committee is made up of employees representing and or involved in: 
¿	Operations
¿	Maintenance
¿	Engineering
¿	Safety 

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
During the last five (5) years no reportable quantities leaked or spilled that would require reporting or affecting the community. There are ammonia odors that occasionally come from packing valve stems, draining oil, and refrigeration cooling coils. These are repaired in a timely manner and investigated. VDF is committed to improve process safety by investigating incidents that would cause, or reasonably could have caused, significant injury or damage, and taking steps to eliminate the causes.

An incident investigation is performed if an ammonia odor is reported by non-refrigeration personnel, or when an incident results in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a large ammonia release.  Two primary types of investigations are provided for: Odor Investigations and Major Incident Investigations. The appropriate type of investigation is left up to the team leader which includes assembling an investigation team, completing the appropriate forms, documenting pertinent information, and implement corrective measures

HOT WORKS
A hot works permit procedure is used at VDF for safe execution of burning, welding, or other types of Hot Works. This procedure defines minimum requirements for preparation of equipment and the protection of personnel prior to and during Hot Works. The Hot Work Permit System is part of the overall VDF Safety and Health Accident Prevention Program. This applies to VDF employees and contractors on site involved with Hot Works.  This procedure must be used with the Lockout/Tagout Procedure when Hot Works is to be performed on machinery or equipment that needs to be de-energized before work can begin. If at all possible and wher

e practical, Hot Work such as welding, cutting or grinding is done in a welding shop or Maintenance area away from process areas.  In addition VDF has implemented a line break procedure and permit system anytime a line break in the ammonia system has to be done.


PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
Process Safety Information (PSI) enables affected employees and contactors working in the ammonia processes to identify and understand the hazards posed by those processes.  This is accomplished through a program which compiles and maintains written Process Safety Information.  

Process Safety Information for existing systems begins by collecting component data (manufacturer, model number, NB number, etc) from the field.  More detailed information may be available from existing company files. New installations and modifications, information is generally obtained from the manufacturers by contractor doing the change. Information gathered is filed electronically on a VDF network drive in a series of folders reserved and labeled for that purpose. A project in which field components are added or substituted for another (with different specifications), is purged of obsolete information from the file, and new information is added.  Field changes are made following the Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review programs. These procedures provide a specific guide as to what information must be added, and then a check to verify completion. 

Safety Data Sheets for ammonia, compressor oil, and any other chemicals necessary to support the ammonia system is compiled and maintained by the Safety department as part of the Hazard Communication program. 

Process technology is defined on documents such as a simplified PFD, a statement of maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower limits for process parameters, and evaluations of the consequence of deviation from those limits. Equipment Technology is documented using P&IDs, U forms (for vessels), cut sheets and product bu

lletins from manufacturers.  Electrical classification is defined, and electrical drawings regarding the ammonia system are compiled.  The relief design and relief design basis are given.  The design basis for the ventilation system is given.  Codes and standards by which the portions of the system were developed are defined.  Safety systems are defined by type and function.

Wherever possible, PSI documents demonstrate equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good practices.  Existing equipment designed and constructed in accordance with codes, standards, or practices that are no longer in general use, documentation shows equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested and operating in a safe manner.  

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS
VDF now performs Process Hazard Analyses internally using methods that provide a thorough, orderly and systematic analysis of the process hazards.  Typically, the What-if or What-if/Checklist method is used.  A PHA form is available for use.  Pages can be used on paper or in electronic format. The VDF Process Hazard Analysis addresses:
¿	The hazards of the process
¿	The identification of any previous incidents with a likely potential for catastrophic consequences
¿	Engineering and administrative controls and detection methods
¿	Facility siting
¿	Human factors
¿	A qualitative analysis of the safety and health affects of failures of controls on workers

PHA's are performed by a team having knowledge of engineering and process operations.  At least one team member has experience and knowledge specific to the process being evaluated.  One other team member is knowledgeable in the specific PHA method to be used.

OPERATING PROCEDURES

Operating Procedures are divided into two major portions: Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) and Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).  A third portion of the procedures, a document called Safety and Health Considerations, applies to all operating procedures.  Operating Pro

cedures must be used in conjunction with Life Critical procedures for maintenance or other work. The TOS section includes information regarding:
¿	Major equipment
¿	Controls with function description, operating limits and consequences of deviation
¿	Safety systems and their functions

The SOP section provides clear instruction for safely conducting activities in various operating phases as appropriate:
¿	Initial startup
¿	Startup after emergency shutdown
¿	Monitor normal operations
¿	Normal shutdown
¿	Emergency shutdown

Safety and Health Considerations contains:
¿	Ammonia properties
¿	Precautions to prevent exposure
¿	Control measures/First aid
¿	Safety devices

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

VDF requires Management of Change for new ammonia facilities and for modifications that are not "replacement in kind" made to its ammonia refrigeration facilities. The MOC is a 3 step procedure that uses forms to document the process.

A VDF employee initiates a change by completing Step 1 of the Management of Change Form and submitting it to the process engineer or his delegate.  The MOC# is obtained from the MOC log using sequential numbers.  The process engineer completes much of Step 2, defining what must be done to meet Process Safety requirements.  A meeting is then held with those performing and those approving the change to clarify the reasons and requirements for making the change.  Once the team agrees on the task list and assigns the tasks, approval is given for the change to proceed by signature in Step 3.  Completed forms are scanned and stored with other PSM documentation. If a change is to be made in the field, a Pre-Startup Safety Review is required before ammonia is charged to the new system.  The exceptions are a Replacement-in-Kind or a very minor change.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
Mechanical Integrity remains the highest priority and is the nuts and bolts of the PSM program. Inspections and observations of our ammonia system is a priority.
VDF M

aintenance Department administers the Mechanical Integrity program, and provides resources necessary for implementation.  The PSM Committee provides guidance and support as necessary. Mechanical Integrity applies to all vessels, equipment, controls, ESD systems, relief devices and systems, and piping in the ammonia systems. Procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity of the equipment are written and implemented.

Preventive Maintenance (PM) is performed with the assistance of a mechanical refrigeration contractor and by VDF refrigeration personnel. PM is performed on all four of the VDF ammonia systems. PM is conducted weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annually. PM is documented with the use of checklists for each time period. In addition each engine room has a log book of the work activity and inspections that remains in the engine room for review.

Inspection and testing is performed on the equipment in accordance with generally accepted good engineering practices, and on a frequency consistent with manufacturer's standards and good engineering practices. Relief valves are changed every five years.

Deficiencies outside acceptable limits are corrected before further use or in a timely manner when means are taken to assure safe operation. Only equipment that is suitably fabricated for that purpose is used in the construction of new plants and equipment.  The Change Leader who oversees the implementation construction of a new project is required to assure equipment is installed properly and consistent with manufacturer's instructions.  



PRE STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW
The primary objective of the Pre Startup Safety Review Program (PSUSR) is to verify that the items specified on the Management of Change (MOC) are completed as specified by the approvers before the full implementation of the change in the field. PSUSR policy requires that the tasks are documented as they are completed, rather than waiting until the end of the project.  As the project or chang

e implementation reaches completion, the project leader requests a PSUSR team. This team meets to perform the PSUSR.  Part of the meeting they will be performing a walk-through to check for project completeness. In preparation for the PRUSR meeting, the change leader brings a copy of the MOC form showing all the requirements for making the change and those assigned to perform them. The team reviews the progress of the items on the MOC form.  Once the form is complete and signed, ammonia may be put into the new system.
CONTRACTORS
Contractors who perform maintenance, repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to one of Van Drunen Farm's ammonia refrigeration systems undergo screening, understand the nature of their work, conduct themselves safely, and provide safe method instruction to their employees. This program does not apply to contractors providing incidental services which do not influence process safety, such as janitorial work, food and drink services, laundry, delivery or other supply services.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS
An audit for the four ammonia systems was performed June 30, 2013 by an outside consultant with the skill and knowledge pertaining to an ammonia system. A report with findings and recommendations was provided.

An audit of VDF's PSM program will be performed at least every 3 years by an auditor(s) who is knowledgeable in the process.  Auditor(s) are not primarily responsible for the implementation of the program elements to be reviewed.  The auditor develops a report of the findings and issues it to the facility manager.  The facility manager would determine an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and documents that the deficiencies were corrected.  The two most recent compliance audit reports are retained.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE
An audit for the four ammonia systems was performed June 30, 2013 by an outside consultant with the skill and knowledge pertaining to ammonia systems. A r

eport with findings and recommendations was provided.

An audit of VDF's PSM program will be performed at least every 3 years by an auditor(s) who is knowledgeable in the process.  Auditor(s) are not primarily responsible for the implementation of the program elements to be reviewed.  The auditor develops a report of the findings and issues it to the facility manager.  The facility manager would determine an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and documents that the deficiencies were corrected.  The two most recent compliance audit reports are retained.

A used ambulance was purchased from a neighboring community and converted into an Emergency Response Vehicle. Equipment needed to respond primarily to an ammonia leak is kept in the Emergency Response Vehicle. The vehicle is kept at a central location away from the VDF facilities that contain ammonia.

The VDF Emergency Response Team responds to all incidents using the Incident Command System (ICS). The ICS is an organization framework that has its own pre-established flexible chain of command, and an Incident Commander to execute overall responsibilities.  

The Command function is led by the Incident Commander (IC. We currently have more than one trained IC. During non business hours, the Operations Manager is also normally closest to the plant.  In any case, the ICs decide among themselves who will be the active IC.  The active IC immediately gathers and analyzes the available information to decide whether to initiate a response.  If the building has not yet been evacuated, IC decides that as well.  If an evacuation is ordered, it is done according to the Evacuation Plan. In any case, VDF has no operating employees who remain behind for critical plant operations. 

Early in the response process, the IC determines what agencies to notify, who will make the notifications and when.  Using the Pre-Emergency Planning Drawings developed by the Pre-plan team and with input fro

m knowledgeable team members, IC formulates an Action Plan for the response.  IC then assigns qualified members to fill the necessary operation and logistical roles.  If support is required from the Police or Fire Departments, the IC interfaces with their leaders to define those needs.  During the entire emergency response, the IC and the Safety Officer have responsibility for the safety of all members of the team.  One IC can relieve another during a response, but in all cases the lines of authority go to the active IC.

The greatest share of the planning is performed and documented ahead of time during Pre-emergency planning sessions by the Pre-plan sub-team.  Their work is documented on drawings which show the floor plan of the buildings as well as pictures of the valves or controls that need to be operated to best mitigate a release in each area.  Additional planning is done at the beginning of each response to tailor the general Pre-plans into the Action Plan for that situation.  This Action Plan is then executed by the Operations group.  

Additional work that may be necessary such as neighborhood evacuations, more extensive security, or EMT services is normally provided by the Momence Police and Fire Departments. 

TRADE SECRETS
If a person is required by the PSM standard to know information which is considered a trade secret, VDF ensures that information is made available to him/her. If appropriate, a confidentiality agreement is drawn up and signed.
